qas.question: Which standard of time started with British Railways?
When was GMT adopted by British Railways?
GMT used what instead of atomic clocks?
When did observations at the Greenwich Observatory cease?
The terms GMT and Greenwich Mean Time are also used informally to refer to what?
In what year did British railways go into business?
What did the British railway stop using in 1954?
What did Greenwich Mean Time replace in 1847?
How constant is an atomic clock?

plausible_answers.text: the duration of a second would vary

qas.question: What happens when an atomic clock is not constant?
Which standard of time started with the International Astronomical Union?
When was GMT adopted by the International Astronomical Union?
The International Astronomical Union used what instead of atomic clocks?
When did observations at the Greenwich Observatory begin?
The term calibrated is also used informally to refer to what?

context: <a0_0><b10_0>Greenwich Mean Time<b10_0/><a0_0/> (GMT) is an older standard, adopted starting with British railways in <a1_0><b5_0><b11_0>1847<b11_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>. Using <a2_0><b12_0>telescopes<b12_0/><a2_0/> instead of atomic clocks, GMT was calibrated to the mean solar time at the Royal Observatory, Greenwich in the UK. <b7_0>Universal Time<b7_0/> (UT) is the modern term for the international telescope-based system, adopted to replace <b6_0>"Greenwich Mean Time"<b6_0/> in 1928 by the International Astronomical Union. Observations at the Greenwich Observatory itself ceased in <a3_0><b13_0>1954<b13_0/><a3_0/>, though the location is still used as the basis for the coordinate system. Because the rotational period of Earth is <b8_0>not perfectly constant<b8_0/>, <b9_0>the duration of a second would vary<b9_0/> if calibrated to a telescope-based standard like GMT or UT—in which a second was defined as a fraction of a day or year. The terms "GMT" and "Greenwich Mean Time" are sometimes used informally to refer to <a4_0><b14_0>UT or UTC<b14_0/><a4_0/>.
